key_insight: A modular teleoperation interface plus a scalable learning framework with "choice policies" lets a humanoid robot select and coordinate submodules (hands, head, arms, legs) for robust whole-body manipulation in human environments.
problem_solved: Addresses the difficulty of achieving robust, interpretable whole-body coordination across head, hands, and legs for humanoid manipulation tasks, reducing complexity of direct end-to-end control.
method: Design a modular teleoperation interface that decomposes control into intuitive submodules: hand-eye coordination, grasp primitives, arm end-effector tracking, and locomotion.
Introduce "choice policies" (a scalable selector/gating mechanism) that dynamically choose and blend among submodules to produce coherent whole-body actions.
Train the system from teleoperation demonstrations and scalable learning (imitation + reinforcement-style refinement) to generalize coordinated behaviors and enable sim-to-real transfer.
impact: Makes training and deploying coordinated humanoid behaviors more scalable and interpretable, enabling researchers and engineers to combine intuitive human teleoperation data with modular learning to tackle complex manipulation in real-world settings.
visual_elements: Architecture diagram: modular teleoperation interface (submodules) feeding into choice-policy selector and whole-body controller
Decision-flow graphic: example timeline showing how the choice policy switches/blends primitives during a pick-and-place with stepping
Before/after or benchmark chart: performance (success rate, efficiency) comparing end-to-end vs modular + choice policies
Sequence storyboard: snapshots of a humanoid performing coordinated manipulation (look, reach, grasp, step) with annotated module activations
paper_title: Coordinated Humanoid Manipulation with Choice Policies
paper_authors: Haozhi Qi, Yen-Jen Wang, Toru Lin, Brent Yi, Yi Ma
